w:r.w:t: Motivation and Student Engagement in Online Mathematics Homework
Thank you very much for participating in the study on
Motivation and Student engagement in online mathematics homework
insights into your profile based on your motivation and engagement reports during the course
information is provided regarding the beneficial role of motivation and engagement for learning, as well as
your average scores in motivation and engagement
average scores of the whole study population.
B1. How are these scores calculated?
These scores have been calculated based on the average of your responses to the surveys. The responses ranged from 1 “Strongly disagree” to 6 “Strongly Agree”.
the surveys, which you did not answer,
you will receive information about the whole study population only
. More about the measurement of motivation and engagement can be found
ime points: at the beginning and the end of Q3. The two following aspects of motivation were examined: a)
(for more information about these aspects, please can read
). Figures 1 and 2 show your scores in comparison with the whole study
In this study, engagement was measured during online mathematics homework in Grasple. Engagement was measured at four
time points during Q2 (Weeks 3-7). You were asked to report on your engagement right after you had completed your practice in Grasple.
The three following dimensions of student engagement were examined:
a) Affective Engagement, b) Behavioural Engagement, and c) Cognitive Engagement (for more information about these aspects, please can read
). Figures 3, 4, and 5 show your scores in comparison with the whole study population.
B4. Take a minute to reflect on your scores
, please take a minute to think about your scores as illustrated in the tables and figure
How high or low your score is at a specific time point in an absolute scale (0-6)?
How high or low your score is at a specific time point compared to the average score of the whole study population?
How does your score change across different points?
How is this change related to the change of
What do motivation and student engagement mean and why would I want to improve them?
“Do I Want to Do This Task?”
“Do I Want to Do This Task?”
If your score on Values Beliefs is high, then you believe that your mathematics homework is very useful for your studies.
If your score on Values Beliefs is high, then you believe that your mathematics homework is very useful for your studies.
If your score on Expectancy Beliefs is high, then you believe that you are able to successfully work and complete your mathematics homework.
If your score on Expectancy Beliefs is high, then you believe that you are able to successfully work and complete your mathematics homework.
Strong motivation requires both expectancy and value beliefs to be high.
High expectancy and value beliefs (or else high motivation)
Strong motivation requires both expectancy and value beliefs to be high.
High expectancy and value beliefs (or else high motivation)
The extent to which you exert effort during learning activities.
The extent to which you exert effort during learning activities.
The extent to which you feel activated during learning activities.
The extent to which you feel activated during learning activities.
The extent to which you are absorbed during learning activities
The extent to which you are absorbed during learning activities

If your score on Cognitive Engagement is high, then you are very focused and concentrated when solving your mathematics homework. Furthermore, you think about ways to solve the exercises and connect your homework with what you already know.

If your score on Cognitive Engagement is high, then you are very focused and concentrated when solving your mathematics homework. Furthermore, you think about ways to solve the exercises and connect your homework with what you already know.
If your score on Behavioural Engagement is high, then you are careful when solving mathematics homework and try hard to complete all the exercises.
If your score on Behavioural Engagement is high, then you are careful when solving mathematics homework and try hard to complete all the exercises.
In case your Affective Engagement is high, then you feel enjoyment and interest when working on your mathematics homework. Moreover, your levels of alertness are high, while boredom is low.
In case your Affective Engagement is high, then you feel enjoyment and interest when working on your mathematics homework. Moreover, your levels of alertness are high, while boredom is low.
If your scores on all the engagement components are high, then your engagement is more “powerful” resulting in better performance in your mathematics course.
If your scores on all the engagement components are high, then your engagement is more “powerful” resulting in better performance in your mathematics course.
How can you improve your motivation and engagement?
In this section, you will find some general strategies
improving motivation and engagement in homework.
and have more control over your learning progress
by describing useful features for effective goal setting

As an exercise, you could think about the next important mathematics topic you will have to learn. Try to set three goals for what to study and three goals for how to study. You could use the SMART framework to create your goals.
about the relevance of the mathematics task
Understanding the usefulness and relevance of the mathematics task can be beneficial for motivation and behavioural engagement. Research studies suggest that the two following exercises can
Ask your mathematics teacher or an older student to
information about the usefulness and relevance of
Try to generate your own arguments that prove the usefulness and relevance of the learning material for accomplishing your current and future goals.
overcome possible difficulties to succeed in the
provide you with evidence about your skills and abilities which can boost your motivation.
existing feedback can act as a practice that drives enhanced motivation and engagement.
Constructive feedback is specific, and includes justifications and suggestions for improvement.
Making mistakes is an important part of the learning process.
view effort and persistence, asking for help, and adjustment of strategies as necessary step
These students adopt a “growth mindset” towards learning and are more likely to successfully respond to academic challenges. You can learn more about growth mindset
